content: The Act titled "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress before reaching the debt limit. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress 60-21 days before the public debt reaches the specified limit. The Treasury Secretary must report to Congress before the public debt reaches the specified limit, providing information on the state of the debt, including historical levels, current amount, composition, and future projections. The Secretary must submit a report on the public debt, including historical levels, current amount, composition, future projections, Federal revenue levels, drivers of future debt, and the impact of raising the debt limit. The report must include projections of the debt, historical Federal revenue levels, drivers of future debt, and measures to fund obligations if the debt limit is not raised. The report must include projections of the debt, historical Federal revenue levels, drivers of future debt, and measures to fund obligations if the debt limit is not raised, including how the United States will meet debt obligations and any reduction measures the Secretary intends to take. The report must include projections of the debt, historical Federal revenue levels, drivers of future debt, and measures to fund obligations if the debt limit is not raised. This includes notifying Congress when the limit has been reached and when the Secretary has begun taking measures, as well as recommending a balanced budget amendment to control future debt accumulation. The President must provide detailed proposals to reduce public debt in the short, medium, and long term, as well as recommend a balanced budget amendment to control future debt accumulation. The President must provide detailed proposals to reduce public debt in the short, medium, and long term, as well as address the impact of an increased debt limit on future Government spending and the position of the United States dollar as the international reserve currency. The President must provide detailed proposals to adjust the debt-to-GDP ratio, assess the impact of an increased debt limit on future Government spending, debt service, and the position of the US dollar as the international reserve currency, project the fiscal health of major entitlement programs, and outline plans for each week the US Government's debt remains high. The President must provide detailed proposals to adjust the debt-to-GDP ratio, assess the impact of an increased debt limit on future Government spending, debt service, and the position of the US dollar as the international reserve currency, project the fiscal health of major entitlement programs, and outline plans for each week the US Government's debt remains high, including reduction measures to avoid defaulting on obligations. The Department of the Treasury must publicly disclose reduction measures used to avoid defaulting on government obligations, including total dollar amounts for each measure. The Department of the Treasury must disclose reduction measures used to avoid defaulting on government obligations, including total dollar amounts for each measure and the estimated remaining funds available. The Secretary will also provide the date when all reduction measures will be exhausted. The Secretary will disclose the date when all reduction measures will be exhausted and the Government will begin defaulting on its obligations, along with any extraordinary measures intended to fund Federal government obligations if the debt limit is not raised. The Secretary will disclose the date when reduction measures will be exhausted, leading to default on obligations. Extraordinary measures to fund Federal government obligations if the debt limit is not raised will be outlined, along with projections of how long they will last and the associated administrative costs. The Administration's technological capability to pay only principal and interest on the national debt will also be addressed. The report will include details on the progress of implementing the President's proposals, projections of administrative costs for extraordinary measures, and the Administration's technological capability to pay only principal and interest on the national debt. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide a progress report on implementing the President's proposals, but only if a Secretary has appeared at least once for a particular President. Reduction measures involve issuing debt through the Federal Financing Bank for specific purposes. Reduction measures defined in this section include directing debt issuance by the Federal Financing Bank, suspending investments in the Government Securities Investment Fund, and suspending investments in the stabilization fund under section 5302 of title 31, United States Code. The reduction measures include suspending investments in various funds, selling or redeeming assets, and limiting debt transactions. The reduction measures include suspending new investments in the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund or the Postal Service Retiree Health Benefits Fund, selling or redeeming securities before maturity, and implementing other appropriate measures as determined by the Secretary.
